div.head: Introduction
div.p: The texts included in The Swinburne Project are encoded in TEI/XML. That is, the texts are encoded in XML following the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, version P5.

div.head: ODD and Schema Files
div.p: The TEI system utilizes an ODD (One Document Does It All) file to select a subset of the available TEI modules (collections of related elements and attributes). If necessary, the ODD file can also describe modifications to standard TEI structures and mechanisms. From the ODD file, one programmatically derives a validating DTD, W3C schema, or RelaxNG Schema.

&tsp; ODD file includes the following TEI modules:
core
Elements common to all TEI documents. tei
Declarations for datatypes, classes, and macros available to all TEI modules. header
The TEI Header. textstructure
Default text structure. figures
Tables, formulae, and figures. namesdates
Names and dates. linking
Linking, segmentation and alignment. transcr
Transcription of primary sources. msdescription
Manuscript Description. analysis
Simple analytic mechanisms. drama
Performance texts. verse
Verse structures. corpus
Header extensions for corpus texts. tagdocs
Documentation of TEI modules. nets
Graphs, networks and trees
Individual &tsp; TEI/XML files use the RelaxNG (compact syntax) schema, derived from the &tsp; ODD file, for validation.

div.head: Bibliographic Elements
div.p:
When citing Web-based electronic publications, many citations formats require that one include both the publication date and the date of access. The type attribute on date is used to distinguish between these two, and potentially other, dates within a single bibliographic entry found in a bibl, biblStruct, or biblFull element. For example:
TEI Consortium, ed. TEI P5: Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange. Vers. 1.6.0. TEI Consortium, 20 Feb. 2010. Web. 4 Apr. 2010. .

div.head: Epigraphs
div.p:
Epigraphs may occur in a number of permutations. For example:
Epigraphs containing just a quotation
Epigraphs containing a quotation and some form of bibliographic citation, in which both elements (quotation and bibliographic citation) are rendered as block elements.
Epigraphs containing a quotation and some form of bibliographic citation, in which the bibliographic citation is inline in the same block of text as the quotation.

div.head: Songs embedded in longer poems, dramas, etc.
div.p: Swinburne's dramas and longer poems like Tristram of Lyonesse contain embedded songs, which are rendered distinctly from the surrounding text.
These are best handled on a case by case basis using a combination of rendition and rend. See example below which handles both the left-indent (using rend and the smaller text (using rendition).

lg.l: And Tristram smiled and changed his song and sang.
"The breath between my lips of lips not mine,
Like spirit in sense that makes pure sense divine,
Is as life in them from the living sky
That entering fills my heart with blood of thine
And thee with me, while day shall live and die.
"Thy soul is shed into me with thy breath,
And in my heart each heartbeat of thee saith
How in thy life the lifesprings of me lie,
Even one life to be gathered of one death
In me and thee, though day may live and die.
"Ah, who knows now if in my veins it be
My blood that feels life sweet, or blood of thee,
And this thine eyesight kindled in mine eye
That shows me in thy flesh the soul of me,
For thine made mine, while day may live and die?
"Ah, who knows yet if one be twain or one,
And sunlight separable again from sun,
And I from thee with all my lifesprings dry,
And thou from me with all thine heartbeats done,
Dead separate souls while day shall live and die?
"I see my soul within thine eyes, and hear
My spirit in all thy pulses thrill with fear,
And in my lips the passion of thee sigh,
And music of me made in mine own ear;
Am I not thou while day shall live and die?
"Art thou not I as I thy love am thou?
So let all things pass from us; we are now,
For all that was and will be, who knows why?
And all that is and is not, who knows how?
Who knows? God knows why day should live and die."
And Iseult mused and spake no word, but sought
Through all the hushed ways of her tongueless thought
What face or covered likeness of a face
In what veiled hour or dream-determined place
She seeing might take for love's face, and believe
This was the spirit to whom all spirits cleave.
For that sweet wonder of the twain made one
And each one twain, incorporate sun with sun,
Star with star molten, soul with soul imbued,
And all the soul's works, all their multitude,
Made one thought and one vision and one song,
Love—this thing, this, laid hand on her so strong
She could not choose but yearn till she should see.
So went she musing down her thoughts; but he,
Sweet-hearted as a bird that takes the sun
With clear strong eyes and feels the glad god run
Bright through his blood and wide rejoicing wings,
And opens all himself to heaven and sings,
Made her mind light and full of noble mirth
With words and songs the gladdest grown on earth,
Till she was blithe and high of heart as he.
So swam the Swallow through the springing sea.
